GREEN POWER ON BROWNFIELDS PROJECT
ASSISTANCE TO STATE LEGISLATURES ON ENERGY ISSUES
VARIOUS OUTREACH ACTIVITIES TO U.S. INDUSTRY AND FOREIGN GOVERNMENT AGENCIES

AS PART OF ITS PRIMARY OBJECTIVES, THE SDSU IAC WILL IDENTIFY NEW AND INNOVATIVE WAYS TO ACCOMPLISH DOE’S PROGRAMMATIC GOALS FOR MANUFACTURERS, SUCH AS ORGANIZING WORKSHOPS, SEMINARS, ETC. TO DELIVER IAC SERVICES THAT COINCIDE WITH DOE PRIORITIES INCLUDING SMART MANUFACTURING, CYBERSECURITY, ENERGY MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS – AND WASTE WATER TREATMENT PLANTS.  THE PERFORMANCE GOALS ARE ALIGNED WITH THOSE OUTLINED BY DOE, AND FOCUSED ON THE FOLLOWING - PROVIDING A HIGH-QUALITY EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCE FOR ABOUT 10 ENGINEERING STUDENTS PER YEAR, AWARDING A DOE CERTIFICATE TO A MINIMUM OF FIVE STUDENTS PER YEAR, EXECUTING A PARTNERSHIP AND OUTREACH PLAN SUCH AS WORKSHOP, TO INCREASE PROGRAM IMPLEMENTATION AND PROVIDE ENERGY AND WATER SAVING ASSISTANCE TO NONPARTICIPANTS, PROVIDING HIGH QUALITY, VALUE ADDED SERVICES TO SMES, INCLUDING CYBERSECURITY, SMART MANUFACTURING, ENERGY MANAGEMENT, WASTE REDUCTION, SUSTAINABILITY & PRODUCTIVITY IMPROVEMENTS AND OTHER LEADING ISSUES. 
THE POTENTIAL IMPACT AND OUTCOME OF THE PROJECT IS HAVING HIGHLY TRAINED ENERGY ENGINEERS, COMPETITIVE SMES WITH MORE EFFICIENT ENERGY USE, LEAN MANUFACTURING, AND SECURE CYBER USE.  IT ALSO SERVES AS A FEEDBACK TO FACULTY FOR QUALITY TEACHING AND PRODUCTIVE RESEARCH.  TO ACCOMPLISH THESE GOALS, THE TEAM WILL EFFECTIVELY COORDINATE EFFORTS WITH DOE AND LOCAL MANUFACTURING GROUPS, TRADE ASSOCIATIONS, UTILITY EFFICIENCY PROGRAMS, AND STATE ENERGY PROGRAMS.

THE PROPOSED PROJECT AIMS TO ESTABLISH AN INDUSTRIAL ASSESSMENT CENTER AT UNIVERSITY OF NORTH TEXAS (UNTIAC). THE CENTER’S OBJECTIVES ARE (1) TO ASSIST SMALL AND MEDIUM-SIZED ENTERPRISES (SMES) BETTER MANAGE ENERGY, WATER, AND WASTE, INCREASE PRODUCTIVITY AND COMPETITIVENESS, IDENTIFY OPPORTUNITIES FOR SMART MANUFACTURING, RESILIENCY PLANNING, DECARBONIZATION AND ELECTRIFICATION, AND IMPROVE CYBER SECURITY, AND (2) TO PROVIDE TRAINING FOR STUDENTS TO BE BETTER PREPARED AND MORE PRODUCTIVE IN THE MARKET PLACE.
QUALIFYING COMPANIES ARE INITIALLY SURVEYED BY THE CENTER TEAM OF STUDENTS AND FACULTY TO DETERMINE THE PRODUCTS, TECHNOLOGIES, PROCESSES, INFORMATION SUPPORT, AND SUPPLY CHAIN SYSTEMS USED. A FULL DAY ASSESSMENT OF THE PLANT IS THEN CONDUCTED BY THE TEAM. AS A RESULT, A FORMAL REPORT IS GENERATED BY THE TEAM AND SUBMITTED TO THE COMPANY. THE REPORT DETAILS RECOMMENDATIONS FOR IMPROVEMENTS BASED ON THE ASSESSMENT CONDUCTED, DATA, AND INFORMATION COLLECTED. THE RECOMMENDATIONS PROVIDE DETAILED ESTIMATES OF ENERGY AND OTHER COST SAVINGS OPPORTUNITIES, IMPLEMENTATION COSTS, AND PAYBACK PERIOD. FOLLOW UP SESSIONS ARE CONDUCTED BY THE CENTER DIRECTOR WITH COMPANY MANAGEMENT TO INSURE PROPER IMPLEMENTATION OF THE RECOMMENDATIONS MADE AND NURTURE THE PARTNERSHIP.
THE REALIZATION OF THE CENTER WILL HAVE THE FOLLOWING IMPACTS.
1. ASSIST SMALL AND MEDIUM SIZE COMPANIES IN THE AREAS EMPHASIZED FOR THIS PROJECT INCLUDING NON-PARTICIPATING COMPANIES THROUGH THE ADOPTION OF TOOLS, APPLICATIONS, AND BEST PRACTICES DEVELOPED BY THE CENTER AND MADE AVAILABLE TO THEM
2. PROVIDE SUPERIOR TRAINING AND EXPERIENCE TO ENGINEERING STUDENTS
3. CERTIFY STUDENTS IN DOE RELEVANT AREAS
4. DEVELOP RELEVANT CURRICULA TO ADDRESS THE AREAS OF EMPHASIS OF THE CENTER
5. PROVIDE A QUALIFIED WORKFORCE TO TEXAS ECONOMY AND BEYOND

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PERFORM 125 MEDIUM-PLANT ASSESSMENTS, SUBSTITUTING A TWO-DAY LARGE-PLANT 
ASSESSMENT FOR TWO MEDIUM-PLANT ASSESSMENTS WHERE APPROPRIATE AND APPROVED BY THE FIELD MANAGER. THE 
OBJECTIVE IS TO SAVE THESE PLANTS ON AVERAGE 7400 MMBTU OF PRIMARY ENERGY (FUEL SAVINGS PLUS ELECTRICAL SAVINGS 
DIVIDED BY LOCAL ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION EFFICIENCY) IN IMPLEMENTED SAVINGS. ON THE TRAINING FRONT, THEY WILL HAVE 
INVOLVEMENT OF AT LEAST 12 STUDENTS AT ANY GIVEN TIME. AT LEAST 5 CERTIFICATES OF PARTICIPATION WILL BE DELIVERED PER 
YEAR. COMPLEMENTING THE DIRECT CENTER TRAINING OF STUDENTS, THE TEAM WILL CONTINUE TO DEVELOP CURRICULA THAT 
INCLUDES TRAINING IN ENERGY EFFICIENCY. FURTHERMORE, CYBERSECURITY MITIGATION WILL BE INCORPORATED INTO OUR 
ASSESSMENTS.
THE PROJECT TEAM WILL PERFORM THIS OBJECTIVE BY A COMBINATION OF AGGRESSIVELY FINDING ENERGY SAVINGS 
RECOMMENDATIONS INCLUDING LONGER TERM PAYBACK ONES THAT THEY “SELL” TO THE PLANT, WHILE ALSO FINDING THE LOWER 
PAYBACK ONES THAT SELL THEMSELVES. IN ADDITION, THE TEAM HAVE A NOVEL QUICK PRELIMINARY REPORTING STYLE TO THE 
PLANT RESULTING IN FAST RECOGNITION OF THE MAGNITUDE OF SAVINGS OPPORTUNITIES WHICH ENHANCES IMPLEMENTATION. THE 
UNIVERSITY OF DELAWARE INDUSTRIAL ASSESSMENT CENTER HAS FOR ITS PREVIOUS TERMS PERFORMED IN AN EXEMPLARY 
FASHION, WITH 175 ASSESSMENTS PERFORMED INCLUDING SEVERAL LARGE PLANT ASSESSMENTS, RESULTING IN AN AVERAGE 
IMPLEMENTED ANNUAL ENERGY SAVINGS OF 7,359 MMBTU PER PLANT WITH AN ANNUAL IMPLEMENTED DOLLAR SAVINGS OF 
$77,235 PER PLANT. THEIR IMPLEMENTATION RATE OF 3.2 RECOMMENDATIONS PER PLANT APPEARS ON A PAR WITH THE BEST 
CENTERS, AND OUR AVERAGE NUMBER OF RECOMMENDATIONS PER PLANT OF 8.2 SHOWS OUR DRIVE TO UNCOVER EVERY 
POTENTIAL OPPORTUNITY FOR ENERGY SAVINGS. THEY HAVE SHOWN THE EXPERTISE AND DEDICATION TO IDENTIFY A WIDE RANGE 
OF ENERGY SAVINGS RECOMMENDATIONS INCLUDING BOTH STANDARD AND NOVEL TYPES. IN 2012 WE WERE AWARDED THE 
CENTER OF EXCELLENCE IN RECOGNITION OF OUR PERFORMANCE. THEIR CENTER IS SITUATED IN THE DEPARTMENT OF ELECTRICAL 
AND COMPUTER ENGINEERING, WITH INVOLVEMENT OF THE MECHANICAL ENGINEERING DEPARTMENT AND THE CENTER FOR 
ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY AND HAS INVOLVED STUDENTS ACROSS THE COLLEGE OF ENGINEERING. FURTHERMORE, 
WITH BEING IN THE ELECTRICAL AND COMPUTER ENGINEERING DEPARTMENT, THEY WILL BE ABLE TO DRAW UPON OUR 
DEPARTMENT’S STRONG PROGRAM IN CYBERSECURITY TO INCORPORATE CYBER THREAT MITIGATION INTO OUR ASSESSMENTS. ON 
THE EDUCATION FRONT, DURING THEIR OPERATION A MINOR IN SUSTAINABILITY IN ENERGY HAS BEEN ESTABLISHED AT THE 
UNIVERSITY OF DELAWARE, WITH THE DIRECTOR AS THE CHAIRMAN OF THE MINOR, AND A GRADUATE PROGRAM IN ELECTRIC 
POWER AND RENEWABLE ENERGY. THIS INCLUDES COURSE DEVELOPMENT BY THE DIRECTOR INCLUDING A BROAD SURVEY 
COURSE ON ENERGY AND ENERGY EFFICIENCY. GOING FORWARD THERE WILL CONTINUE TO BE ENERGY COURSE AND CURRICULA 
DEVELOPMENT.
WHILE THEY HAVE BARELY TOUCHED THE SURFACE OF PLANT OPPORTUNITIES AND THEIR CENTER WILL CONTINUE TO PRODUCE 
ENERGY SAVINGS IN THE DELMARVA AREA, AND GIVEN THEIR STRONG EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS IN BOTH ENERGY AND 
CYBERSECURITY, THEY WILL PROVIDE INVALUABLE SERVICE TO THE REGION’S MANUFACTURERS, AS WELL AS TRAIN THE NEXT 
GENERATION OF ENERGY PROFESSIONALS.

PROJECT TITLED SAN JUAN COLLEGE ELECTRIC VEHICLE TECHNICIAN CERTIFICATION PROGRAM
NEW AWARD

SINCE 2016, THE SOLSMART PROGRAM HAS HELPED LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (LGS) REDUCE SOFT COST BARRIERS TO SOLAR MARKET 
DEVELOPMENT AND MADE IT EASIER FOR RESIDENTS TO INSTALL RESIDENTIAL SOLAR ENERGY SYSTEMS. THE NEXT PHASE OF THE 
SOLSMART PROGRAM WILL EXPAND LG PARTICIPATION, INCORPORATE NEW TECHNOLOGIES AND TOPICS, AND FURTHER ACCELERATE 
THE DEPLOYMENT OF SOLAR ENERGY, WHILE ADVANCING KEY PRIORITIES AROUND EQUITABLE ENERGY ACCESS AND 
ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE (EJ).  THE NEW SOLSMART PROGRAM WILL SET A GOAL OF DESIGNATING AT LEAST 500 NEW 
COMMUNITIES, FOR AN OVERALL GOAL OF DESIGNATING ALMOST 1,000 SOLSMART COMMUNITIES ACROSS THE UNITED STATES 
BETWEEN 2016-2027. 

THE SOLSMART PROGRAM WILL ADVANCE EJ PRIORITIES THROUGH TWO KEY STRATEGIES. FIRST, THE PROGRAM WILL PRIORITIZE 
RECRUITMENT ACTIVITIES AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO UNDERSERVED OR DISADVANTAGED COMMUNITIES, INCLUDING RURAL 
COMMUNITIES, LGS WITH LIMITED RESOURCES, AND LGS WITH SUBSTANTIAL LOW AND MODERATE INCOME (LMI) POPULATIONS. 
SECOND, THE PROGRAM WILL PRIORITIZE HIGH IMPACT TA SUPPORT IN ALL COMMUNITIES INTENDED TO HELP FACILITATE SOLAR 
ADOPTION AMONG HISTORICALLY DISADVANTAGED POPULATIONS AND BY ASSOCIATED INSTITUTIONS (SCHOOLS, COMMUNITY 
CENTERS, ETC.) AND BUSINESSES. THESE STRATEGIES WILL BE DESIGNED TO INCREASE THE DISTRIBUTION OF BENEFITS IN THESE 
COMMUNITIES, INCLUDING COST SAVINGS, PRICE STABILIZATION, AND ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS. OF 500 NEW LGS DESIGNATED, 
200 WILL BE UNDERSERVED OR DISADVANTAGED COMMUNITIES, AS DEFINED IN THE FOA OR PROVIDED BY DOE’S JUSTICE40 
ANALYSIS. OF THE 1,000 LG STAFF RECEIVING DIRECT TRAINING THROUGH THE PROGRAM, 400 WILL BE STAFF EITHER FROM 
UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES OR PARTICIPATING IN TRAININGS FOCUSED ON ADVANCING EJ-FOCUSED CRITERIA AND TECHNICAL 
ASSISTANCE.

OTHER NEW ELEMENTS OF THE SOLSMART PROGRAM WILL INCLUDE THE INTEGRATION OF ADDITIONAL SETO PROGRAMS AND TOOLS, 
SUCH AS INCENTIVES FOR ADOPTION OF SOLARAPP+; A GREATER FOCUS ON USING SOLAR PLUS TECHNOLOGIES, SUCH AS SOLAR + 
STORAGE; AND AN INCREASING FOCUS ON OTHER TOPICS, SUCH AS CODES AND STANDARDS; SITING AND ZONING FOR COMMERCIAL 
AND UTILITY-SCALE SOLAR SYSTEMS; SOLAR FINANCING; SOLARIZE CAMPAIGNS; AND OTHER ACCELERATED DEPLOYMENT STRATEGIES. 
SOLSMART WILL PURSUE AN AMBITIOUS COMMUNICATIONS PROGRAM TO RE-ENGAGE WITH PREVIOUSLY DESIGNATED 
COMMUNITIES, DEVELOP NEW TOOLS AND RESOURCES IN LINE WITH NEW PROGRAM PRIORITIES, AND BUILD AWARENESS OF THE 
PROGRAM ACROSS THE COUNTRY. SOLSMART WILL SET A GOAL OF “LEVELING UP” AT LEAST 200 PREVIOUSLY DESIGNATED 
COMMUNITIES AND DOCUMENT AT LEAST 6,000 PUBLIC ENGAGEMENTS OR USE OF PROGRAM OUTPUTS, INCLUDING 
COMMUNICATIONS CONTENT, DOWNLOADS OF REPORTS OR RESOURCES, AND ATTENDEES TO PUBLIC WEBINARS OR CONFERENCE 
PRESENTATIONS. 

FINALLY, THE SOLSMART PROGRAM WILL DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT AN IMPACT EVALUATION STRATEGY DESIGNED TO MEASURE 
THE IMPACTS OF THE SOLSMART PROGRAM IN REDUCING SOFT COSTS, REDUCING PERMITTING AND INSPECTION (PI) TIMELINES, 
AND ACCELERATING THE ADOPTION OF SOLAR ENERGY IN DESIGNATED COMMUNITIES ACROSS THE COUNTRY. THE PROGRAM WILL 
IMPLEMENT A NEW STRATEGY FOR BASELINE DATA COLLECTION AND FOLLOW-ON REPORTING TO BETTER TRACK PROGRAM IMPACTS IN 
INCREASED SOLAR DEPLOYMENT IN SOLSMART COMMUNITIES BEYOND BUSINESS-AS-USUAL GROWTH EXPECTATIONS. WORKING 
WITH AN EXTERNAL EVALUATOR AND CONTROL GROUP ANALYSIS, THE PROGRAM WILL ESTABLISH A GOAL OF DEMONSTRATING THAT 
SOLSMART DESIGNATION LEADS TO A 50% DECREASE IN INSTALLATION TIMELINES IN DESIGNATED COMMUNITIES, A 25% 
INCREASE IN SOLAR DEPLOYMENT WITHIN DESIGNATED COMMUNITIES, AND A TOTAL OF 500 MW OF ADDITIONAL ROOFTOP 
RESIDENTIAL SOLAR ENERGY DEPLOYED ACROSS THE UNITED STATES.

GSA REGION 4 WATER CONSERVATION MEASURE - USE OF AQUIFER WATER FOR COOLING TOWER MAKEUP AT 3 BUILDINGS

THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE TO EDUCATE DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION PROFESSIONALS ON KEY PRINCIPALS OF INTEGRATING SOLAR ENERGY INTO THE BUILT ENVIRONMENT.  THE SCOPE OF THE EFFORT WILL BE FOCUSED ON ARCHITECTURAL SOLAR; THE PROJECT TEAM DEFINES ARCHITECTURAL SOLAR AS SOLAR ENERGY GENERATING TECHNOLOGY THAT HAS ARCHITECTURAL SIGNIFICANCE OR IS COORDINATED WITH THE ARCHITECTURAL DESIGN PROCESS. WHETHER IT BE A BUILDING-INTEGRATED PHOTOVOLTAIC (BIPV) FACADE OR A ROOFTOP PV SYSTEM THAT IS ARCHITECTURALLY COORDINATED WITH ROOFTOP VENTS EARLY IN THE DESIGN PROCESS, IT IS ENCOMPASSED BY THE TERM ARCHITECTURAL SOLAR. THE EDUCATIONAL CONTENT WILL ENCOMPASS BOTH RESIDENTIAL AND COMMERCIAL MARKETS WHEN IT COMES TO COMMUNICATING THE NEEDS OF “SOLAR-READY” PRINCIPALS, ALTHOUGH THE MAJORITY OF THE CONTENT WILL BE FOCUSED ON THE COMMERCIAL MARKET WHERE THE LARGEST KNOWLEDGE GAPS HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED. THE INITIAL CONTENT WILL START WITH A HIGH-LEVEL OVERVIEW OF ARCHITECTURAL SOLAR AND PROGRESS TO MORE IN-DEPTH TECHNICAL MODULES THAT TARGET SPECIFIC USER-GROUPS. EXAMPLES OF POTENTIAL TOPICS INCLUDE INTEGRATION FEASIBILITY, FINANCIAL ANALYSIS, SYSTEM DESIGN AND WORKFLOW PRINCIPALS.

NEW AWARD TITLED, CREATING THE NFPA DISTRIBUTED ENERGY RESOURCES SAFETY TRAINING (DERST) PROGRAM

THE PURPOSE OF THE ENERGY PARTNERSHIPS PROJECT 5.0, LIKE THE PRECEDING SIMILAR PROJECTS, IS TO INCREASE THE SIZE AND IMPACT OF THE FEDERAL WEATHERIZATION ASSISTANCE PROGRAM (WAP) THROUGH PARTNERSHIPS THAT BRING NON-FEDERAL RESOURCES TO WAP PROJECTS AND ORGANIZATIONS. SPECIFICALLY, THE PROJECT WILL HELP WAP ORGANIZATIONS IDENTIFY AND CONNECT WITH POTENTIAL FUNDING PARTNERS, SUCH AS HOUSING AND COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT INVESTORS, HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS AND THEIR FOUNDATIONS, RENEWABLE ENERGY INDUSTRIES, AND, OF COURSE, UTILITIES NOT ALREADY COUNTED AS WAP PARTNERS. THE TOOLS AND TRAININGS THAT ARE PRODUCTS OF THE PROJECT ARE INTENDED TO HELP WAP AGENCIES DESIGN EFFECTIVE COLLABORATIONS AND ADAPT PROVEN TOOLS AND TEMPLATES TO NEW PROJECTS. SUCH PROJECTS CAN INCLUDE ADDITIONAL RESOURCES FOR EFFICIENCY OR RENEWABLE MEASURES AND MORE FUNDING FOR HOUSING IMPROVEMENT AND NON-WEATHERIZATION CLIMATE ADAPTATION INVESTMENTS IN ELIGIBLE HOMES AND DISADVANTAGED COMMUNITIES.

THE PROJECT TEAM WILL PROVIDE INFORMATION AND ASSISTANCE TO THE WEATHERIZATION NETWORK AND OUR POTENTIAL PARTNERS THROUGH NATIONAL CONFERENCE WORKSHOPS, ON-LINE TRAINING THROUGH WEBINARS AND INTERACTIVE WORKSHOPS NEWSLETTERS, MULTIMEDIA PRODUCTS, PEER EXCHANGES AND OFFERING INDIVIDUALIZED ASSISTANCE. NATIONAL COMMUNITY ACTION PARTNERSHIP (NCAP) WILL ALSO KEEP THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY (DOE) APPRISED OF DEVELOPMENTS THAT AFFECT LOCAL CAPACITY TO ENGAGE IN LEVERAGING AND PARTNERSHIP INITIATIVES IN THE WEATHERIZATION NETWORK. FURTHERMORE, IF WEATHERIZATION IS SUBSTANTIALLY EXPANDED THROUGH LEGISLATION, THE PROJECT WILL COMMUNICATE WITH SUBGRANTEES REGULARLY TO TRACK IMPLEMENTATION SUCCESSES AND BARRIERS AND TO MEET THEIR INFORMATION AND NETWORKING NEEDS BY CREATING MATERIALS TO ASSIST.

GRANTEE TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROJECT
•DEVELOP AND DELIVER TRAINING, PROVIDE SUPPORT AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY (DOE) WEATHERIZATION ASSISTANT PROGRAM (WAP) GRANTEE MANAGERS AND STAFF.
•COORDINATE AND CONDUCT ENERGY RELATED TRAINING AND ORIENTATION CONFERENCES FOR WAP GRANTEE MANAGERS AND WAP SUBGRANTEES.
•ASSIST AND ENHANCE WAP COMMUNICATIONS, IMPROVING COMMUNICATION EFFORTS OF GRANTEES AND INCREASING OVERALL PROGRAM AWARENESS.
•GATHER AND DISSEMINATE BEST PRACTICES, MODEL POLICIES, AND OTHER CRITICAL INFORMATION ACROSS THE WAP NETWORK.

THE PROJECT WILL HAVE A SOLAR PV RENEWABLE ENERGY SYSTEM, AND DEMONSTRATE THAT THE ECONOMICS OF THE SYSTEM CAN BE IMPROVED BY PARTICIPATION IN OPEN MARKET PROGRAMS. UTILIZING THE ESA, WITHIN AN ESPC APPROACH TO ASSET OWNERSHIP, WILL REDUCE THE AMOUNT OF ADDITIONAL APPROPRIATED OR GRANT FUNDS NEEDED TO IMPLEMENT THE RESILIENCY MEASURES OF THIS PROJECT. THE INITIAL OBJECTIVE WILL BE TO DEVELOP AN INVESTMENT GRADE AUDIT AND AWARD A TASK ORDER UNDER THE ESPC CONTRACT FOR THE DESCRIBED SCOPE. FOLLOWING THAT ORDER, THE CONSTRUCTION OF THE MEASURES, INTERCONNECTION WITH THE UTILITY AND ACCEPTANCE OF THE PROJECT WILL BE PERFORMED. ONCE THESE ARE PROVEN, GSA HAS A MAJOR OBJECTIVE OF TAKING THE LESSONS LEARNED AND REPLICATING THE RESULTS TO OTHER LPOES AND GSA FACILITIES.

CONSERVATION TECHNOLOGIES (AFFECT) FUNDING TO EXPAND AN EXISTING ENERGY SAVINGS PERFORMANCE CONTRACT (ESPC) PROJECT TO IMPROVE ENERGY EFFICIENCY AND RESILIENCY AT A MISSION CRITICAL DATACENTER AT OPM’S HEADQUARTERS, THE THEODORE ROOSEVELT BUILDING (TRB). THE PROPOSED UPGRADES WERE ANALYZED AS PART OF THE PROJECT’S PRELIMINARY ASSESSMENT (PA) AND DRAFT INVESTMENT GRADE AUDIT (IGA) AND WOULD BE PERFORMED UNDER A TASK ORDER MODIFICATION TO THE EXISTING ESPC CONTRACT.
